text:
Best interview advice I have is to go deep vs. broad.
• Tell me about your most successful content project?
• How did this project come about? (do they understand business goals)
• What were the challenges you encountered along the way?
• Who did you work with on this project?
• What would you do differently (are they always getting better)
• What was the impact? (business impact again)
Really try to understand their process & thinking.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: The most important benefit is running review campaigns for us. We ran a test and ran our own review campaign via email before launching one with them. We got 2 new reviews. Our recent G2 campaign got us 15.

elements.text: The most important benefit is running review campaigns for us. We ran a test and ran our own review campaign via email before launching one with them. We got 2 new reviews. Our recent G2 campaign got us 15.

text: Then we use those reviews as content everywhere. Marketing campaigns. Sales cycles. Tradeshow booths. They allow us to be labelled as leaders in our categories. It creates a side by side comparison with our competitors that looks great (but that's thanks to happy customers, not G2).

text:
I just went back and looked at the packages they sent me at our last renewal. $32K would definitely be one of the higher-end packages, which might include lead generation and buyer intent data.

So the short answer is, there’s tons of ROI if you have a strategy and use the features to their full capacity. But it sounds like maybe your client doesn’t have a strategy yet?

text:
Hey folks!

This is a bit random question but let's imagine that you got an extra $1m budget for your content projects. 

How would you use it to scale/grow your business? 

I work for a SaaS company and been asked this question. Curious to hear your ideas :) and sorry it's a bit random.

elements.text: Hey folks!

This is a bit random question but let's imagine that you got an extra $1m budget for your content projects. 

How would you use it to scale/grow your business? 

I work for a SaaS company and been asked this question. Curious to hear your ideas :) and sorry it's a bit random.

text: I’d probably just retire… but I’m a freelancer so I guess it’s a little different for me :sweat_smile:

elements.text: I’d probably just retire… but I’m a freelancer so I guess it’s a little different for me

text: But definitely following this to see what people say.

elements.text: But definitely following this to see what people say.

elements.text: Yea :D I'm afraid both my family and my boss wouldn't be happy if I followed your suggestion

elements.text: Yeaahhhh probably shouldn’t lol.

text:
*Option 1*: Scale organic traffic. Hire a bunch of writers and editors. Publish 10 times a day about super top-of-funnel stuff. This is pretty much what Masterclass is doing with their many millions.

You get tons of traffic and wide brand awareness (also a sky-high bounce rate, brand malaise, and no real audience-building).

*Option 2*: Do the most expensive, least-evergreen thing for your niche. Might be a live digital marketing news show, roundtables with experts about in-the-moment topics, whatever.

Lots of opportunity to differentiate and build a loyal audience (since few others could afford to do it and lots of immediate value for the audience), but you'd better be ready for a short shelf life for content and lots of tough-to-report increases in brand affinity (or, of course, the potential for the whole thing to flop).

*Option 3*: Build a research engine. Create a sustainable source of research from which you can create whatever kind of content you want (evergreen, non-evergreen, text, video, etc.).

This one is probably what I'd want to do. Research reports are great for branding (e.g., U.S. News & World Report) and ensure proprietary information in a me-too content marketing world.

With a bunch of money, you could actually do it right (e.g., code/automate data pulls, validate results with data scientists, establish a peer review system).

elements.text: Option 1

: Scale organic traffic. Hire a bunch of writers and editors. Publish 10 times a day about super top-of-funnel stuff. This is pretty much what Masterclass is doing with their many millions.

You get tons of traffic and wide brand awareness (also a sky-high bounce rate, brand malaise, and no real audience-building).
Option 2

: Do the most expensive, least-evergreen thing for your niche. Might be a live digital marketing news show, roundtables with experts about in-the-moment topics, whatever.

Lots of opportunity to differentiate and build a loyal audience (since few others could afford to do it and lots of immediate value for the audience), but you'd better be ready for a short shelf life for content and lots of tough-to-report increases in brand affinity (or, of course, the potential for the whole thing to flop).
Option 3

: Build a research engine. Create a sustainable source of research from which you can create whatever kind of content you want (evergreen, non-evergreen, text, video, etc.).

This one is probably what I'd want to do. Research reports are great for branding (e.g., U.S. News & World Report) and ensure proprietary information in a me-too content marketing world.

With a bunch of money, you could actually do it right (e.g., code/automate data pulls, validate results with data scientists, establish a peer review system).

text:
This is a super interesting question. I have to think it depends a lot on current state and also industry - are we talking about a product that’s $6/mo or $600? My answer assumes a relatively high-ticket, B2B product with a long-ish buying cycle and existing powerful organic engine.

If I had money and the kind of DA that makes acquisition relatively easy, I’d focus on interactive pieces (using something like Ceros) - and I LOVE <@UJDPMTREY>’s option 3 above about creating independent research. This is where the biggest PR value is, I think, and great PR can drive a lot of things. Original research + polished, interactive research product goes a long way to establish a dominant thought leadership position IMHO.

elements.text:

If I had money and the kind of DA that makes acquisition relatively easy, I’d focus on interactive pieces (using something like Ceros) - and I LOVE

’s option 3 above about creating independent research. This is where the biggest PR value is, I think, and great PR can drive a lot of things. Original research + polished, interactive research product goes a long way to establish a dominant thought leadership position IMHO.

text:
Thanks for your answers, <@UJDPMTREY> and <@U016AG4A2G2>!

Re. Derek’s anwers:

1. I’ve certainly seen plenty of companies dominate the SERPs with their SEO-content and it seems like a game that has no end. You need to keep adding more writers, build more links, refresh your content, find better keywords, etc. I’d love to follow this to a certain point, but not 100% of the time (plus we’re in a very competitive niche)
2. This one’s interesting but not sure $1m would cut it :smile:. In our sector, MailChimp’s spending tons of money on their video initiatives and I guess it’d be enough for only one or two of their episodes. It’s remarkable stuff, but doesn’t seem to be scalable.
3. I’m a big fan of original research for sure. We’ve tried it a few times and I can see we need to still learn a lot (especially in terms of promotion), but it’s generated decent results in certain aspects (backlinks, mentions, leads), but our tracking isn’t ideal so it’s difficult to assign a specific number to these initiatives.
<@U016AG4A2G2> In our case, it’s a product that starts at $15/mo so we’re talking small accounts where we’re trying to keep our CPL very low.

elements.text: Thanks for your answers,
and

!

You need to keep adding more writers, build more links, refresh your content, find better keywords, etc. I’d love to follow this to a certain point, but not 100% of the time (plus we’re in a very competitive niche)
This one’s interesting but not sure $1m would cut it

. In our sector, MailChimp’s spending tons of money on their video initiatives and I guess it’d be enough for only one or two of their episodes. It’s remarkable stuff, but doesn’t seem to be scalable.

I’m a big fan of original research for sure. We’ve tried it a few times and I can see we need to still learn a lot (especially in terms of promotion), but it’s generated decent results in certain aspects (backlinks, mentions, leads), but our tracking isn’t ideal so it’s difficult to assign a specific number to these initiatives.
In our case, it’s a product that starts at $15/mo so we’re talking small accounts where we’re trying to keep our CPL very low.

text: What's the burndown time on the budget?  It's hard to imagine committing $1M to _anything_, wholesale.  I think I'd want to take some slices of that money, devise some fixed scope experiments, and then invest the rest in the ones that brought the best return, after reasoning about up-front and maintenance cost.

elements.text: What's the burndown time on the budget?  It's hard to imagine committing $1M to
anything

, wholesale.  I think I'd want to take some slices of that money, devise some fixed scope experiments, and then invest the rest in the ones that brought the best return, after reasoning about up-front and maintenance cost.

text: So, as a crude example, without knowing the specifics of the SaaS, maybe you'd invest $20K each in a blitz on blog content, video/streaming content, and owned podcast content, and see which channel(s) did the best against your KPIs.  You wouldn't want to let it play out for too long with money just sitting in the bank, but you could create some interim evaluation criteria that would still be pretty good after a limited time, and then you could tune the investment as you went.

elements.text: So, as a crude example, without knowing the specifics of the SaaS, maybe you'd invest $20K each in a blitz on blog content, video/streaming content, and owned podcast content, and see which channel(s) did the best against your KPIs.  You wouldn't want to let it play out for too long with money just sitting in the bank, but you could create some interim evaluation criteria that would still be pretty good after a limited time, and then you could tune the investment as you went.

text: But one less common thing that I'd probably invest that in, personally, if I held the purse strings, was infrastructure and training of staff to repurpose content across media super efficiently, Gary V, style.

elements.text: But one less common thing that I'd probably invest that in, personally, if I held the purse strings, was infrastructure and training of staff to repurpose content across media super efficiently, Gary V, style.

text: One other fairly off the wall thing that occurs to me (and this is more wearing an investor/business owner hat) if you really had to commit quickly to the money or lose it... you could create a separate, niche site instrumented for organic traffic, flood it with content and have the parent company SaaS as an advertiser/sponsor.  Then it's generating some leads for you, but you could also instrument for affiliate marketing and flip it later to recoup your investment (and then some, if you did it right) and have cash back in your pocket later.

Then it's generating some leads for you, but you could also instrument for affiliate marketing and flip it later to recoup your investment (and then some, if you did it right) and have cash back in your pocket later.
